title: May be afraid of strangers
description: Baby may cry or cling when unfamiliar people approach. This is normal stranger anxiety and shows healthy attachment.
sourceQuote: Most babies this age are shy, clingy, or fearful around strangers. This is a normal part of development.

title: Has favorite toys
description: Baby shows clear preferences for certain toys or objects and may get upset if they are taken away.
sourceQuote: By 9 months, most babies have favorite toys and may cling to them or get upset when they are taken away.

title: Understands 'no'
description: Baby pauses or stops briefly when you say 'no,' showing they understand the word even if they don't always comply.
sourceQuote: By 9 months, most babies understand 'no' and will briefly pause or stop when they hear it.

title: Makes many different sounds
description: Baby babbles strings of sounds like 'mamamama' or 'babababa' and experiments with different consonant-vowel combinations.
sourceQuote: By 9 months, most babies make a lot of different sounds like 'mamamama' and 'babababa,' stringing consonants and vowels together.

title: Watches the path of a falling object
description: Baby tracks objects that fall and looks for them, showing developing understanding of object permanence.
sourceQuote: By 9 months, most babies watch the path of something as it falls and look for things they see you hide.

title: Looks for hidden objects
description: When you hide a toy under a blanket, baby tries to find it. This demonstrates growing memory and understanding that things still exist when out of sight.
sourceQuote: By 9 months, most babies look for things they see you hide, showing they understand objects still exist when out of sight.

title: Stands holding on
description: Baby can pull up to standing using furniture or your hands and briefly hold the position while supported.
sourceQuote: By 9 months, most babies can pull to stand and stand holding on to furniture or other support.

title: Can get into sitting position
description: Baby can push up from tummy or roll into a sitting position without help and sit steadily without support.
sourceQuote: By 9 months, most babies can get to a sitting position by themselves and sit without support.

title: Plays peek-a-boo
description: Baby actively participates in peek-a-boo games, laughing and sometimes trying to initiate the game themselves.
sourceQuote: Around this age, babies love simple games like peek-a-boo and will laugh and try to keep the game going by hiding and reappearing.

title: Shows preferences for certain people
description: Baby clearly prefers familiar caregivers and may reach for specific people, showing developing social bonds.
sourceQuote: Babies at this age develop strong preferences for familiar caregivers and may reach for or crawl toward their favorite people.

title: Responds to own name consistently
description: Baby reliably turns toward you when you call their name, showing they recognize and respond to it.
sourceQuote: By this age, your baby should consistently turn toward you when you call their name, a key sign of social and language development.

title: Uses gestures to communicate
description: Baby waves bye-bye, shakes head, or uses other gestures along with babbling to express wants and feelings.
sourceQuote: Babies begin using gestures such as waving bye-bye and shaking their head to communicate before they can use words.

title: Explores objects in different ways
description: Baby shakes, bangs, throws, and drops objects to discover what they do, experimenting with cause and effect.
sourceQuote: Babies explore objects by shaking, banging, throwing, and dropping them to discover how things work and what they can do.

title: Crawls well
description: Baby moves around efficiently on hands and knees or by scooting, exploring the environment more independently.
sourceQuote: Hands-and-knees crawling is a key motor milestone, with most children achieving proficient crawling between 8 and 11 months.

title: Uses pincer grasp
description: Baby picks up small objects between thumb and index finger with increasing precision.
sourceQuote: The pincer grasp, picking up small objects between thumb and forefinger, is an important fine motor milestone that typically develops around 9 to 10 months.

title: Shows separation anxiety
description: Baby may cry or become distressed when a primary caregiver leaves the room. This peaks around this age and is a normal sign of attachment.
sourceQuote: Separation anxiety is common at this age and is a sign of the strong bond your baby has formed with you. It typically peaks around 10 to 12 months.

title: Enjoys social games
description: Baby laughs during interactive games like pat-a-cake and may try to keep the game going by repeating actions.
sourceQuote: Babies love interactive games like pat-a-cake and will try to keep a fun game going by repeating actions and looking at you expectantly.

title: Babbles with expression
description: Baby's babbling begins to sound like real conversation, with rising and falling tones that mimic speech patterns.
sourceQuote: Your baby's babbling may start to sound like real conversation, with rising and falling tones that mimic the patterns of your speech.

title: Understands simple instructions
description: Baby begins to follow simple requests like 'give me that' or 'come here' when paired with gestures.
sourceQuote: Around this age, babies begin to understand simple requests such as 'give me that' or 'come here,' especially when accompanied by gestures.

title: Imitates actions
description: Baby copies simple actions they observe, like clapping hands, stirring with a spoon, or talking on a phone.
sourceQuote: Babies learn through imitation, copying everyday actions they see like clapping, stirring, or pretending to talk on the phone.

title: Cruises along furniture
description: Baby walks sideways while holding onto furniture, building leg strength and balance for independent walking.
sourceQuote: Walking with assistance, including cruising along furniture, is a normal transitional motor milestone that typically occurs between 9 and 12 months.

title: May stand alone briefly
description: Baby can let go of support and stand independently for a few seconds before sitting back down.
sourceQuote: Standing alone is a milestone most children achieve between 9 and 14 months, beginning with brief moments of independent standing.

title: Is shy or nervous with strangers
description: Baby may hide behind caregiver or cry around unfamiliar people. This shows healthy attachment and social awareness.
sourceQuote: By 12 months, most children are shy or nervous with strangers. This is a normal sign that your child knows the difference between familiar and unfamiliar people.

title: Hands you a book to read
description: Baby brings objects to you for help or to share, showing early cooperative communication and shared attention.
sourceQuote: By 12 months, most babies hand you a book when they want to hear a story, showing they can communicate their wants through actions.

title: Repeats actions that get attention
description: Baby does things to get a reaction, like making silly sounds or dropping food, then looking at you to see your response.
sourceQuote: By 12 months, most babies repeat sounds or actions to get attention and see how you react. This shows growing social awareness.

title: Says 'mama' and 'dada' with meaning
description: Baby uses 'mama' and 'dada' (or similar) specifically for parents rather than as random babbling.
sourceQuote: By 12 months, most babies say 'mama' and 'dada' and use them to call for the specific parent, not just as babbling.

title: Tries to say words you say
description: Baby attempts to copy words they hear, even if the pronunciation isn't quite right yet.
sourceQuote: By 12 months, most babies try to say one or two words besides 'mama' and 'dada,' like 'ba' for ball or 'da' for dog.

title: Finds hidden objects easily
description: Baby can find a toy hidden under a blanket or cup, showing solid understanding of object permanence.
sourceQuote: By 12 months, most babies can find hidden things easily and understand that objects continue to exist even when they can't be seen.

title: Starts to use objects correctly
description: Baby uses everyday objects appropriately - drinks from a cup, brushes hair, holds phone to ear.
sourceQuote: By 12 months, most babies begin to use things correctly, such as drinking from a cup or brushing their hair.

title: May take first steps
description: Some babies begin walking independently around 12 months, though the normal range is 9-15 months.
sourceQuote: By 12 months, some babies may take a few steps without holding on. The normal range for first steps is 9 to 15 months.

title: Uses pincer grasp confidently
description: Baby picks up small items like cereal pieces between thumb and forefinger with good control.
sourceQuote: By 12 months, most babies pick up things between thumb and pointer finger, like small pieces of food, with good control.

title: Shows affection to familiar people
description: Baby hugs, kisses, or pats familiar caregivers and family members spontaneously.
sourceQuote: Toddlers show affection by hugging, kissing, and patting the people they love. This is a wonderful sign of secure attachment.

title: Plays simple pretend
description: Baby begins very basic pretend play, like pretending to drink from an empty cup or feed a stuffed animal.
sourceQuote: Early pretend play, like pretending to drink from a cup or feed a doll, begins around 12 to 15 months and shows growing imagination.

title: Uses 1-3 words
description: Baby has a few real words beyond 'mama' and 'dada,' though pronunciation may still be approximate.
sourceQuote: By 12 to 15 months, most toddlers use one to three words with meaning, even if pronunciation is still approximate.

title: Points to ask for things
description: Baby points at objects they want and looks at you, combining gesture with vocalization to communicate.
sourceQuote: Pointing to request objects is an important communication milestone that shows your child is learning to share their wants with you.

title: Explores containers
description: Baby enjoys putting objects in and taking them out of containers, exploring spatial relationships.
sourceQuote: Toddlers love filling and dumping containers, which helps them learn about spatial relationships and cause and effect.

title: Walks with one hand held
description: Baby can walk while holding one of your hands for balance, gaining confidence in upright movement.
sourceQuote: Walking with assistance is a normal developmental step, with most children progressing from supported to independent walking between 11 and 15 months.

title: Enjoys being the center of attention
description: Baby performs for an audience, repeating actions that make people laugh and clap.
sourceQuote: Toddlers love an audience and will repeat actions that get laughs and applause, building social confidence and connection.

title: Imitates other children
description: Baby watches and copies what other children do, showing interest in peer interaction.
sourceQuote: Toddlers are fascinated by other children and learn by watching and imitating what they do, which is an early form of social learning.

title: Understands more than says
description: Baby understands many more words than they can say, following simple requests and recognizing familiar objects by name.
sourceQuote: At this age, your toddler understands far more words than they can say. Receptive language develops well ahead of expressive language.

title: Uses exclamations
description: Baby says 'uh-oh' or similar exclamations appropriately in context.
sourceQuote: Toddlers often use exclamations like 'uh-oh!' in the right context, showing they understand the social meaning of these expressions.

title: Stacks two blocks
description: Baby can place one block on top of another, showing improving hand-eye coordination and spatial understanding.
sourceQuote: Stacking blocks is a milestone that shows developing hand-eye coordination, spatial awareness, and the ability to plan and execute actions.

title: Walks more steadily
description: Baby's walking becomes more coordinated with fewer falls, though gait is still wide-legged.
sourceQuote: After beginning to walk independently, children gradually develop a steadier gait with fewer falls over the following weeks and months.

title: Squats to pick up toys
description: Baby can bend down to pick something up from the floor and return to standing without falling.
sourceQuote: The ability to squat down and return to standing shows developing balance and leg strength, a natural progression after learning to walk.

title: Copies other children
description: Baby imitates actions of other kids during play, showing early social learning through observation.
sourceQuote: By 15 months, most toddlers copy other children while playing. This is a healthy sign of social awareness and learning.

title: Shows you an object they like
description: Baby brings toys or objects to show you, seeking to share experiences and get your reaction.
sourceQuote: By 15 months, most toddlers show you an object they like, sharing their interest and seeking your reaction.

title: Tries to say 3 or more words
description: Baby uses several words besides 'mama' and 'dada' to communicate, even if pronunciation isn't perfect.
sourceQuote: By 15 months, most toddlers try to say three or more words besides 'mama' or 'dada,' even if the words aren't clear.

title: Follows simple directions
description: Baby can follow one-step commands like 'give me the ball' or 'sit down' without gestures.
sourceQuote: By 15 months, most toddlers follow directions given without any gestures, like handing you a toy when asked.

title: Points to ask for something
description: Baby uses pointing purposefully to request items or direct your attention to something interesting.
sourceQuote: By 15 months, most toddlers point to ask for something or to get help, an important communication skill.

title: Looks at familiar object when named
description: When you name a familiar object, baby looks at it, showing word comprehension is growing.
sourceQuote: By 15 months, most toddlers look at a familiar object when you name it, showing they connect words to the things around them.

title: Takes a few steps on own
description: Baby walks independently, taking several steps at a time, though may still prefer crawling for speed.
sourceQuote: By 15 months, most toddlers take a few steps on their own, though some may still prefer crawling when they want to move quickly.

title: Uses fingers to feed self
description: Baby self-feeds with finger foods effectively and may attempt to use a spoon.
sourceQuote: By 15 months, most toddlers use their fingers to feed themselves and may try to use a spoon, though messily.

title: Hugs stuffed toys or dolls
description: Baby shows affection toward toys and comfort objects, demonstrating early empathy and nurturing behavior.
sourceQuote: Toddlers begin to show caring behaviors, hugging stuffed animals and dolls, which is an early sign of empathy and nurturing instincts.

title: Helps with getting dressed
description: Baby cooperates during dressing by pushing arms through sleeves or lifting feet for shoes.
sourceQuote: Toddlers start to help with dressing by pushing arms through sleeves or lifting feet, showing growing independence and body awareness.

title: Vocabulary growing to 5-10 words
description: Baby uses more words, including names for familiar people, animals, body parts, or common objects.
sourceQuote: Between 15 and 18 months, most toddlers use 5 to 10 words, including names for people, animals, and favorite objects.

title: Points to body parts when asked
description: Baby can identify nose, eyes, mouth, or tummy when asked 'Where is your nose?' etc.
sourceQuote: Your toddler can now point to several body parts when you name them, showing their understanding of language is growing rapidly.

title: Stacks 3 blocks
description: Baby builds a small tower of three blocks, improving on earlier stacking attempts.
sourceQuote: Building a tower of blocks requires concentration, fine motor control, and spatial awareness, all of which are rapidly developing at this age.

title: Walks well without help
description: Baby walks confidently in most situations, rarely falling, and begins to run clumsily.
sourceQuote: Most children walk independently by 15 to 16 months. Walking alone is one of the six gross motor milestones in the WHO developmental standards.

title: Engages in parallel play
description: Baby plays alongside other children, not yet interacting directly but aware of and interested in peers.
sourceQuote: Playing alongside other children without direct interaction is called parallel play, and it is the most common form of social play for toddlers this age.

title: Shows ownership of objects
description: Baby says 'mine' or clutches toys when others approach, showing developing sense of possession.
sourceQuote: Toddlers begin to claim objects as 'mine,' which is a normal part of developing a sense of self and understanding ownership.

title: Understands simple questions
description: Baby responds to questions like 'Where is the dog?' by looking around or pointing.
sourceQuote: Your toddler can now respond to simple questions by pointing or looking, showing that language comprehension is progressing well.

title: Uses words and gestures together
description: Baby combines pointing with words, like pointing at a cup and saying 'juice.'
sourceQuote: Combining gestures with words, such as pointing and naming, is a sign your toddler is building the foundation for more complex communication.

title: Solves simple problems
description: Baby figures out simple challenges like pulling a string to reach a toy or using a stick to get something.
sourceQuote: Toddlers begin to solve simple problems through trial and error, like pulling a string to bring a toy closer, showing early logical thinking.

title: Climbs onto and off furniture
description: Baby climbs onto low furniture like couches and chairs and can get back down (though not always safely).
sourceQuote: Climbing is a natural extension of walking, and toddlers typically begin climbing onto low furniture as their strength and coordination increase.

title: Scribbles with crayon
description: Baby makes marks on paper with a crayon or marker, showing developing fine motor control.
sourceQuote: Around this age, your toddler may enjoy scribbling with crayons, which builds the fine motor skills needed for later drawing and writing.

title: May have tantrums
description: Baby has emotional outbursts when frustrated, tired, or told 'no.' This is normal as they have big feelings but limited ability to express them.
sourceQuote: Tantrums are normal at this age. Your toddler has big feelings but does not yet have the words or skills to manage them.

title: Plays simple pretend
description: Baby engages in pretend play like feeding a doll, talking on a toy phone, or pretending to cook.
sourceQuote: By 18 months, most toddlers play simple pretend, like feeding a doll or talking on a toy phone. This shows growing imagination.

title: Shows affection to familiar people
description: Baby spontaneously hugs, kisses, and cuddles with parents and familiar people.
sourceQuote: By 18 months, most toddlers show affection to familiar people by hugging, cuddling, or kissing them spontaneously.

title: Tries to say 3 or more words besides 'mama' and 'dada'
description: Baby's vocabulary includes several words for familiar objects, people, and actions.
sourceQuote: By 18 months, most toddlers try to say three or more words besides 'mama' and 'dada,' and words are beginning to have clear meaning.

title: Follows one-step directions without gestures
description: Baby understands and follows simple verbal commands like 'Put it down' without needing you to point or gesture.
sourceQuote: By 18 months, most toddlers follow one-step directions without gestures, like sitting down when you say 'sit down.'

title: Points to show you something interesting
description: Baby uses pointing to share discoveries and direct your attention, not just to request things.
sourceQuote: By 18 months, most toddlers point to show you something interesting, not just to ask for things. This is called joint attention.

title: Knows what ordinary objects are for
description: Baby uses phone, brush, spoon correctly, showing understanding of everyday object purposes.
sourceQuote: By 18 months, most toddlers know what ordinary things are for, like a phone, brush, or spoon, and try to use them correctly.

title: Walks without holding on
description: Baby walks independently and confidently, including on uneven surfaces.
sourceQuote: By 18 months, most toddlers walk without holding on to anyone or anything and may try to walk up steps or run.

title: Drinks from a cup and eats with a spoon
description: Baby can drink from an open cup (with some spilling) and use a spoon to self-feed.
sourceQuote: By 18 months, most toddlers can drink from a cup without a lid and eat with a spoon, though some spilling is normal.

title: Seeks comfort from caregiver
description: Baby runs to parent for comfort when hurt, scared, or upset, using caregiver as a secure base.
sourceQuote: Toddlers use their parents as a secure base, running to them for comfort when hurt or scared, which is a healthy sign of strong attachment.

title: Becomes more independent
description: Baby wants to do things by themselves - holding their own spoon, carrying things, choosing what to wear.
sourceQuote: A growing desire to do things independently is a healthy sign of development. Toddlers want to feed themselves, carry things, and make choices.

title: Vocabulary of 10-20 words
description: Baby's spoken vocabulary continues growing, including names of people, objects, and a few action words.
sourceQuote: Between 18 and 24 months, your toddler's vocabulary grows rapidly, and most children use 10 to 20 words by around 19 months.

title: Uses 'no' frequently
description: Baby says 'no' often, both appropriately and as a way to assert independence.
sourceQuote: Saying 'no' frequently is a normal way toddlers assert independence and test boundaries. It shows growing self-awareness and language use.

title: Identifies pictures in books
description: Baby can point to named pictures in books, like 'Where is the dog?' and find the correct image.
sourceQuote: Toddlers can point to pictures in a book when you name them, showing they connect words to images and are building vocabulary.

title: Carries objects while walking
description: Baby walks while holding toys or objects, showing improving balance and coordination.
sourceQuote: Carrying objects while walking demonstrates improved balance and motor planning, as the child must coordinate movement with holding items.

title: Shows defiant behavior
description: Baby tests boundaries by doing things they know are not allowed while watching your reaction. This is normal and developmentally healthy.
sourceQuote: Testing limits is a normal part of toddler development. When your child breaks a rule and looks at you, they are learning about boundaries.

title: Enjoys helping with household tasks
description: Baby wants to 'help' with sweeping, wiping, putting items in trash, and other simple household tasks.
sourceQuote: Toddlers love to help around the house. Letting them participate in simple tasks builds confidence and a sense of belonging in the family.

title: Combines words and gestures expressively
description: Baby uses more complex combinations of words and gestures to communicate needs and share experiences.
sourceQuote: Combining words with gestures shows your toddler is developing more sophisticated communication skills and learning to express complex ideas.

title: Names familiar pictures
description: Baby can name objects they see in picture books, not just point to them.
sourceQuote: Your toddler can now name familiar pictures in books, moving from pointing to verbally identifying what they see.

title: Sorts shapes
description: Baby can match simple shapes to corresponding holes in a shape sorter with some practice.
sourceQuote: Sorting shapes into matching holes helps toddlers develop spatial reasoning and problem-solving skills as they figure out which piece fits where.

title: Kicks a ball forward
description: Baby can walk up to a ball and kick it (not always accurately), showing coordination of legs and balance.
sourceQuote: Kicking a ball forward requires coordination of balance, leg strength, and motor planning, and typically emerges in the second year of life.

title: Begins running
description: Baby starts running, though the movement may be stiff and they can't yet stop or turn quickly.
sourceQuote: Running develops naturally after walking is well established, and early running may appear stiff with limited ability to stop or change direction.

title: Shows empathy toward others
description: Baby may pat or try to comfort someone who is crying, showing early empathy and emotional awareness.
sourceQuote: Toddlers begin to show empathy by noticing when someone is upset and trying to comfort them, such as patting a crying friend or offering a toy.

title: Plays alongside other children
description: Baby engages in more purposeful parallel play, often imitating what other children are doing nearby.
sourceQuote: Parallel play, where toddlers play side by side and often imitate each other, is the most common way children this age interact with peers.

title: Vocabulary of 20-50 words
description: Baby's spoken vocabulary is growing rapidly. They use words for many everyday objects, people, and actions.
sourceQuote: Your toddler's vocabulary is expanding rapidly, and most children use 20 to 50 words by around 21 months, with new words added regularly.

title: Follows two-step instructions
description: Baby can follow simple two-step commands like 'Pick up the ball and bring it to me.'
sourceQuote: Being able to follow two-step instructions shows your toddler's language comprehension and memory are developing well.

title: Begins sorting by color or shape
description: Baby starts to notice and group objects that are similar in color or shape.
sourceQuote: Sorting by color or shape shows that toddlers are beginning to notice similarities and differences between objects, a key thinking skill.

title: Walks up steps with help
description: Baby can walk up stairs while holding your hand or the railing, placing both feet on each step.
sourceQuote: Walking upstairs with support is a normal motor progression, with most children placing both feet on each step before alternating feet later.

title: Engages in more complex pretend play
description: Baby's pretend play becomes more elaborate - feeding dolls, putting them to bed, having toy conversations.
sourceQuote: Pretend play becomes more elaborate as toddlers create simple scenarios like feeding a doll, putting it to bed, or having pretend conversations.

title: Expresses a wide range of emotions
description: Baby shows joy, anger, frustration, excitement, and sadness more clearly, though managing these emotions is still difficult.
sourceQuote: Toddlers feel a wide range of emotions including joy, anger, frustration, and sadness, but they still need help managing these big feelings.

title: Begins combining two words
description: Baby starts putting two words together, like 'more milk,' 'daddy go,' or 'big dog.'
sourceQuote: Putting two words together, like 'more milk' or 'daddy go,' is a major language milestone that shows your toddler is beginning to form sentences.

title: Uses pronouns (me, mine)
description: Baby starts using simple pronouns, especially 'me' and 'mine,' showing growing self-awareness.
sourceQuote: Using pronouns like 'me' and 'mine' shows growing self-awareness and is a normal step in language development for toddlers this age.

title: Completes simple puzzles
description: Baby can place pieces in simple puzzles with 3-4 large pieces, especially shape-based or picture puzzles.
sourceQuote: Simple puzzles with large pieces help toddlers build problem-solving skills and hand-eye coordination as they figure out where each piece goes.

title: Throws ball overhand
description: Baby can throw a ball forward using an overhand motion, though aim is still developing.
sourceQuote: Throwing a ball overhand requires upper body coordination and motor planning, and most toddlers develop this skill during their second year.

title: Shows interest in other children's emotions
description: Baby notices when other children are happy or upset and may react by watching closely or trying to help.
sourceQuote: Toddlers become increasingly aware of other children's feelings, watching closely when a peer is upset and sometimes trying to help or comfort them.

title: Asserts independence strongly
description: Baby wants to do many things without help and may resist assistance, saying 'I do it!' or 'my turn.'
sourceQuote: Asserting independence, even insisting 'I do it myself!', is a healthy sign that your toddler is developing confidence and self-reliance.

title: Uses 50+ words
description: Baby's vocabulary is expanding rapidly as they approach the 'word explosion' phase.
sourceQuote: Many toddlers experience a 'word explosion' around this age, rapidly adding new words to their vocabulary as they approach 50 or more words.

title: Asks 'what's that?'
description: Baby points at objects and asks their name, showing curiosity and desire to learn new words.
sourceQuote: Asking 'what's that?' shows your toddler's natural curiosity and eagerness to learn new words, which helps fuel rapid vocabulary growth.

title: Builds tower of 4+ blocks
description: Baby can stack four or more blocks into a tower, showing improving fine motor control and spatial thinking.
sourceQuote: Building taller towers of four or more blocks shows improving hand control, concentration, and understanding of balance and spatial relationships.

title: Runs more smoothly
description: Baby's running becomes more coordinated with better ability to stop and change direction.
sourceQuote: As children approach their second birthday, running becomes smoother and more coordinated, with improved ability to stop and change direction.

title: Notices when others are hurt or upset
description: Toddler may pause, look sad, or try to comfort another child or adult who seems upset.
sourceQuote: By 2 years, most toddlers notice when others are hurt or upset and may pause, look sad, or try to comfort them.

title: Plays next to other children and sometimes plays with them
description: Toddler begins moving from parallel play to brief interactive play with peers.
sourceQuote: By 2 years, most toddlers play next to other children and sometimes join in to play with them, a sign of growing social skills.

title: Looks at your face to see how to react in new situations
description: Toddler checks your expression before approaching something new, using your reaction as a guide.
sourceQuote: By 2 years, most toddlers look at your face to see how to react in a new situation. This is called social referencing and is perfectly normal.

title: Points to things in a book when asked
description: Toddler can find and point to specific items on a page when you ask 'Where is the cat?'
sourceQuote: By 2 years, most toddlers point to things in a book when you ask, like 'Where is the bear?' showing growing language comprehension.

title: Says at least two words together
description: Toddler regularly combines two or more words like 'more milk,' 'mommy up,' or 'big truck.'
sourceQuote: By 2 years, most toddlers say at least two words together, like 'more milk' or 'mommy up,' forming the basis of early sentences.

title: Points to at least two body parts when asked
description: Toddler can identify multiple body parts by name, like nose, eyes, ears, hands, feet.
sourceQuote: By 2 years, most toddlers point to at least two body parts when you name them, showing they understand the names for parts of their body.

title: Holds something in one hand while using the other
description: Toddler shows hand dominance and coordination, like holding a jar with one hand while unscrewing the lid with the other.
sourceQuote: By 2 years, most toddlers can hold something in one hand while using the other hand, showing developing coordination and hand dominance.

title: Tries to use switches, knobs, or buttons on a toy
description: Toddler experiments with mechanical toys and devices, figuring out how to operate them.
sourceQuote: By 2 years, most toddlers try to use switches, knobs, or buttons on a toy, showing curiosity about how things work.

title: Kicks a ball
description: Toddler can walk up to a ball and kick it forward with reasonable aim.
sourceQuote: By 2 years, most toddlers kick a ball forward, showing coordination of balance and leg strength.

title: Runs
description: Toddler runs with growing coordination, though may still be somewhat stiff.
sourceQuote: By 2 years, most toddlers run, though their movements may still be somewhat stiff and uneven.

title: Walks up a few stairs with or without help
description: Toddler navigates stairs by stepping up, using a railing or holding a hand if needed.
sourceQuote: By 2 years, most toddlers walk up a few stairs with or without help, placing both feet on each step.

title: Takes turns in simple games
description: Toddler begins to understand taking turns, like rolling a ball back and forth or stacking blocks with a partner.
sourceQuote: Turn-taking begins with simple games like rolling a ball back and forth, building the social skills needed for more complex interactions later.

title: Shows wider range of emotions
description: Toddler expresses pride when accomplishing something, shame when caught doing something wrong, and frustration more articulately.
sourceQuote: Toddlers express an increasingly wide range of emotions, including pride, frustration, and even embarrassment, as their emotional awareness deepens.

title: Uses 2-word sentences regularly
description: Toddler consistently puts two words together to make simple sentences throughout the day.
sourceQuote: Regular use of two-word sentences is a key language milestone, showing your toddler can combine words to express ideas and needs.

title: Refers to self by name
description: Toddler uses their own name when talking about themselves, like 'Rowoon want that.'
sourceQuote: Using their own name to refer to themselves shows your toddler has a clear sense of self-identity and is learning how language represents people.

title: Matches objects to pictures
description: Toddler can match a real object to its picture in a book, showing abstract thinking development.
sourceQuote: Matching real objects to pictures in a book shows developing abstract thinking, as your toddler connects a 3D object to its 2D representation.

title: Jumps with both feet off the ground
description: Toddler begins jumping, getting both feet off the ground at the same time.
sourceQuote: Jumping with both feet leaving the ground requires significant coordination, balance, and leg strength, and typically emerges around 24 months.

title: Pretend play becomes more creative
description: Toddler creates simple scenarios in pretend play, like having a tea party or playing house.
sourceQuote: Pretend play grows more creative as toddlers invent scenarios like tea parties or playing house, using imagination to explore the world.

title: Enjoys doing things independently
description: Toddler insists on doing things 'by myself,' from eating to getting dressed to choosing toys.
sourceQuote: The desire to do things independently is a healthy and important part of your toddler's growing sense of competence and self-confidence.

title: Begins using 3-word phrases
description: Toddler starts stringing three words together, like 'I want milk' or 'Daddy go work.'
sourceQuote: Moving from two-word to three-word phrases is a significant language step, allowing your toddler to express more complex thoughts and needs.

title: Names actions in pictures
description: Toddler can describe what's happening in a picture, like 'dog running' or 'baby sleeping.'
sourceQuote: Naming actions in pictures shows your toddler understands verbs and can describe what is happening, not just name objects.

title: Understands concept of 'one'
description: Toddler begins to understand the concept of 'one' and can give you 'one' of something when asked.
sourceQuote: Understanding the concept of 'one' is an early math skill. When your toddler can hand you one block when asked, they are learning to count.

title: Pedals a tricycle
description: Toddler may begin to pedal a tricycle or ride-on toy, using feet to push along if pedaling is too hard.
sourceQuote: Pedaling a tricycle involves coordinating alternating leg movements, and many toddlers begin to master this skill between 24 and 30 months.

title: Shows concern for crying friend
description: Toddler may bring a toy or pat a crying child, showing developing empathy and social awareness.
sourceQuote: When toddlers try to comfort a crying friend by bringing them a toy or patting them, it shows real empathy is developing.

title: Begins to understand rules
description: Toddler starts to internalize simple rules, though following them consistently is still hard.
sourceQuote: Toddlers start to internalize simple rules and routines, even though consistently following them is still challenging at this age.

title: Uses 'I,' 'me,' and 'you'
description: Toddler uses personal pronouns, though may still mix up 'I' and 'me' sometimes.
sourceQuote: Using personal pronouns like 'I,' 'me,' and 'you' is a notable language milestone, even though mix-ups are common and perfectly normal.

title: Answers simple 'what' questions
description: Toddler can answer 'What is this?' when shown familiar objects.
sourceQuote: Answering simple 'what' questions shows your toddler can process a question and retrieve the right word, an important cognitive and language skill.

title: Stacks 6+ blocks
description: Toddler can build taller towers, showing patience and fine motor improvement.
sourceQuote: Building towers of six or more blocks requires patience, steady hands, and spatial understanding, all of which are growing at this age.

title: Walks on tiptoes
description: Toddler can walk on tiptoes for a few steps, showing balance and leg strength improvement.
sourceQuote: Walking on tiptoes for a few steps demonstrates developing balance, calf strength, and body control in toddlers.

title: Plays with other children briefly
description: Toddler engages in short cooperative play episodes with other children, not just alongside them.
sourceQuote: Brief episodes of cooperative play begin as toddlers move beyond parallel play and start directly interacting with peers during activities.

title: Expresses affection verbally
description: Toddler says 'I love you' or 'I like you' to family members and favorite people.
sourceQuote: Saying 'I love you' is a wonderful milestone that shows your toddler can express deep feelings using words, not just actions.

title: Vocabulary of 100+ words
description: Toddler's vocabulary is growing rapidly, with new words being learned almost daily.
sourceQuote: By this age, most toddlers have a vocabulary of over 100 words and are learning new words almost every day.

title: Asks 'why' and 'where' questions
description: Toddler begins asking question words, showing curiosity about the world.
sourceQuote: Asking 'why' and 'where' questions shows your toddler's growing curiosity and their ability to use language as a tool for learning.

title: Engages in symbolic play
description: Toddler uses one object to represent another, like a banana as a phone or a block as a car.
sourceQuote: Using one object to represent another, like pretending a banana is a phone, shows symbolic thinking, a major cognitive leap for toddlers.

title: Stands on one foot briefly
description: Toddler can balance on one foot for a second or two with or without support.
sourceQuote: Briefly standing on one foot requires advanced balance and core strength, and most children begin to achieve this between 24 and 30 months.

title: Assigns roles in pretend play
description: Toddler directs pretend play by assigning roles: 'You be the mommy, I'm the baby.'
sourceQuote: Assigning roles during pretend play shows advanced social and cognitive skills, as toddlers plan scenarios and direct others in shared stories.

title: Shows awareness of gender
description: Toddler begins to notice and comment on gender differences, like 'She's a girl' or 'He's a boy.'
sourceQuote: Toddlers begin to notice gender differences and may label people as 'boy' or 'girl,' which is a normal part of making sense of the world.

title: Uses short sentences
description: Toddler speaks in 3-4 word sentences regularly, telling you about what they see, want, and feel.
sourceQuote: Speaking in 3- to 4-word sentences allows your toddler to share observations, express needs, and describe feelings more clearly.

title: Strangers understand some speech
description: People outside the family can understand roughly half of what the toddler says.
sourceQuote: By this age, unfamiliar people should be able to understand about half of what your toddler says, a sign of improving speech clarity.

title: Understands 'big' and 'little'
description: Toddler grasps size concepts and can identify which of two objects is bigger or smaller.
sourceQuote: Understanding size concepts like 'big' and 'little' shows your toddler is developing the ability to compare and categorize objects.

title: Walks up stairs alternating feet
description: Toddler begins walking up stairs placing one foot per step instead of both feet on each step.
sourceQuote: Walking up stairs with alternating feet is an advanced motor skill that shows improved balance, strength, and coordination.

title: Plays next to other children and sometimes plays with them
description: Toddler transitions between parallel and cooperative play, beginning to interact more with peers during play.
sourceQuote: By 30 months, most toddlers play next to other children and sometimes play with them, showing growing social awareness and cooperation.

title: Shows you what they can do by saying 'Look at me!'
description: Toddler seeks attention and praise for accomplishments, showing pride in new skills.
sourceQuote: By 30 months, most toddlers say 'Look at me!' to show you what they can do, seeking your attention and approval.

title: Says about 50 words or more
description: Toddler has a substantial vocabulary and is adding words almost daily.
sourceQuote: By 30 months, most toddlers say about 50 words or more and are learning new words regularly.

title: Says two or more words together, with one action word
description: Toddler uses verb-containing phrases like 'doggy run,' 'want cookie,' or 'mommy sit.'
sourceQuote: By 30 months, most toddlers say two or more words together with one action word, like 'doggy run' or 'mommy sit.'

title: Names things in a book when asked
description: Toddler can name familiar objects and characters in picture books.
sourceQuote: By 30 months, most toddlers name things in a book when you point and ask 'What is this?'

title: Uses things to pretend, like feeding a block to a doll
description: Toddler's pretend play becomes more creative and symbolic.
sourceQuote: By 30 months, most toddlers use things to pretend, like feeding a block to a doll as if it were food, showing symbolic thinking.

title: Shows simple problem-solving skills
description: Toddler figures out simple problems like turning a container to dump out contents or stepping on a stool to reach something.
sourceQuote: By 30 months, most toddlers show simple problem-solving skills, like standing on a stool to reach something on the counter.

title: Uses hands to twist things, like turning doorknobs
description: Toddler has the wrist control and strength to turn doorknobs, open jars, and screw lids.
sourceQuote: By 30 months, most toddlers use their hands to twist things, like turning doorknobs or unscrewing lids, showing fine motor growth.

title: Takes some clothes off by themselves
description: Toddler can remove simple clothing like shoes, socks, and hats independently.
sourceQuote: By 30 months, most toddlers take some clothes off by themselves, like shoes, socks, or loose pants.

title: Begins cooperative play
description: Toddler starts playing with other children directly, sharing a goal like building something together.
sourceQuote: Cooperative play, where children work together toward a shared goal, begins to emerge and is a major social milestone for toddlers.

title: Follows simple household routines
description: Toddler understands and follows daily routines like brushing teeth after eating or putting shoes on to go outside.
sourceQuote: Following daily routines shows your toddler understands the sequence of events and can predict what comes next, providing comfort and security.

title: Uses 'and' to connect words
description: Toddler starts using conjunctions to make longer sentences: 'Mommy and Daddy' or 'ball and book.'
sourceQuote: Using conjunctions like 'and' to link words and ideas is a sign of more complex language development emerging in your toddler.

title: Asks many questions
description: Toddler frequently asks 'what,' 'where,' and 'who' questions, eager to learn about everything.
sourceQuote: Asking frequent questions is your toddler's way of learning about the world. Responding patiently helps build vocabulary and understanding.

title: Counts to 3
description: Toddler can count 'one, two, three' objects, though may not always be accurate.
sourceQuote: Counting to three is an early math milestone. Toddlers may recite numbers in order and begin to count small groups of objects.

title: Catches a large ball
description: Toddler can catch a large ball with both arms extended, though coordination is still developing.
sourceQuote: Catching a large ball with both arms requires visual tracking, hand-eye coordination, and timing, skills that develop throughout the toddler years.

title: Shows awareness of others' feelings
description: Toddler recognizes and responds to emotional expressions in others, saying things like 'You sad?'
sourceQuote: Recognizing and naming others' emotions, like asking 'You sad?', shows your toddler's empathy and emotional understanding are growing rapidly.

title: Has favorite friends
description: Toddler shows preferences for certain playmates and may ask for them by name.
sourceQuote: Having favorite friends shows your toddler is forming meaningful social bonds and preferences, an important step in social development.

title: Tells simple stories
description: Toddler recounts simple events from their day, like 'We went park. I played slide.'
sourceQuote: Telling simple stories about their day shows your toddler's memory, sequencing, and narrative skills are developing.

title: Uses 'in,' 'on,' and 'under'
description: Toddler uses spatial prepositions correctly most of the time.
sourceQuote: Using prepositions like 'in,' 'on,' and 'under' correctly shows your toddler understands spatial relationships and can describe them with words.

title: Sorts objects by color
description: Toddler can group objects by color when given direction, like 'Put the red ones here.'
sourceQuote: Sorting objects by color shows your toddler can identify colors and group items by shared characteristics, an early classification skill.

title: Strings large beads
description: Toddler can thread large beads onto a string, showing improving fine motor control and patience.
sourceQuote: Stringing beads requires precise hand-eye coordination and patience, and is a good activity for building fine motor skills at this age.

title: Engages in imaginative play with others
description: Toddler participates in group pretend play, taking on roles and following basic storylines.
sourceQuote: Playing imaginatively with others, taking on roles, and following storylines shows advanced social and cognitive skills developing in your toddler.

title: Understands 'mine' and 'yours'
description: Toddler begins to grasp the concept of ownership beyond just saying 'mine,' understanding that others have possessions too.
sourceQuote: Understanding 'mine' and 'yours' shows your toddler is grasping the concept of ownership and recognizing that others have possessions too.

title: Uses plurals
description: Toddler adds 's' to make words plural: 'dogs,' 'shoes,' 'cookies,' though may over-generalize ('foots').
sourceQuote: Using plurals, even with over-generalizations like 'foots,' shows your toddler is learning grammar rules and applying them to language.

title: Vocabulary of 200+ words
description: Toddler's vocabulary has grown substantially and they learn multiple new words each day.
sourceQuote: By this age, most toddlers have a vocabulary of 200 or more words and continue to learn several new words every day.

title: Completes 4-piece puzzles
description: Toddler can complete simple puzzles with several pieces, showing spatial reasoning growth.
sourceQuote: Completing puzzles with several pieces helps toddlers build spatial reasoning, problem-solving skills, and the persistence needed for more complex tasks.

title: Balances on one foot for 1-2 seconds
description: Toddler can briefly balance on one foot, showing core strength and balance development.
sourceQuote: Balancing on one foot for a second or two requires core stability and leg strength, and is a developing skill for children around this age.

title: Shares toys when asked
description: Toddler can share when prompted, though spontaneous sharing is still developing.
sourceQuote: Sharing when asked shows your toddler can control impulses and respond to social expectations, even though spontaneous sharing takes more time.

title: Shows pride in accomplishments
description: Toddler beams and says 'I did it!' when completing a task, showing self-awareness and confidence.
sourceQuote: Showing pride in accomplishments by saying 'I did it!' reflects your toddler's growing self-awareness and developing sense of competence.

title: Uses past tense
description: Toddler begins using past tense: 'I played,' 'Daddy went,' though may make errors ('I goed').
sourceQuote: Using past tense, even with errors like 'I goed,' shows your toddler is learning grammar rules and applying them to talk about past events.

title: Strangers can understand most speech
description: About 75% of what the toddler says is understandable to unfamiliar people.
sourceQuote: By this age, strangers should understand about 75% of what your toddler says, reflecting improving speech clarity and pronunciation.

title: Names several colors
description: Toddler can identify and name at least 3-4 common colors correctly.
sourceQuote: Naming several colors correctly shows your toddler can categorize visual information and connect it with the right words.

title: Hops on one foot
description: Toddler attempts hopping on one foot, managing 1-2 hops before losing balance.
sourceQuote: Hopping on one foot is an advanced gross motor skill that requires strength, balance, and coordination, and begins to emerge around age 3.

title: Takes turns without much prompting
description: Toddler begins to take turns during play more independently, though still needs reminders.
sourceQuote: Taking turns with less prompting shows your toddler is internalizing social rules and building the self-control needed for cooperative play.

title: Comforts a friend who is upset
description: Toddler spontaneously tries to comfort peers who are hurt or crying, showing maturing empathy.
sourceQuote: Spontaneously comforting a friend who is upset shows real empathy developing, as your child recognizes and responds to others' emotions.

title: Speaks in 4-5 word sentences
description: Toddler's sentences are getting longer and more complex, with better grammar.
sourceQuote: Speaking in 4- to 5-word sentences with improving grammar shows your toddler's language skills are maturing rapidly.

title: Knows some basic songs and rhymes
description: Toddler can sing along to parts of familiar songs and recite simple nursery rhymes.
sourceQuote: Singing songs and reciting rhymes builds memory, rhythm awareness, and language skills in toddlers this age.

title: Understands 'same' and 'different'
description: Toddler can identify when two things are the same or different in basic comparisons.
sourceQuote: Understanding 'same' and 'different' shows your toddler can compare objects and recognize similarities and differences, a key thinking skill.

title: Draws simple shapes
description: Toddler can copy a circle or make a cross, moving beyond random scribbling to intentional shapes.
sourceQuote: Drawing intentional shapes like circles and crosses shows your toddler's fine motor control and visual-motor integration are maturing.

title: Calms down within 10 minutes after separation
description: Child can recover from separation distress relatively quickly when left with familiar caregivers.
sourceQuote: By 3 years, most children calm down within 10 minutes after you leave them, showing they feel secure and trust their caregivers.

title: Notices other children and joins them to play
description: Child actively approaches other children to play, showing social initiative and confidence.
sourceQuote: By 3 years, most children notice other children and join them to play, showing social initiative and growing confidence with peers.

title: Shows concern for a crying friend
description: Child demonstrates empathy by responding to peers' emotions with comfort or concern.
sourceQuote: By 3 years, most children show concern for a crying friend without being told to, demonstrating developing empathy and compassion.

title: Talks with you in conversation using at least two back-and-forth exchanges
description: Child can maintain a simple conversation, responding to what you say and adding their own thoughts.
sourceQuote: By 3 years, most children talk with you in conversation using at least two back-and-forth exchanges, a key communication milestone.

title: Asks 'who,' 'what,' 'where,' or 'why' questions
description: Child asks questions to learn about the world, showing growing curiosity and language sophistication.
sourceQuote: By 3 years, most children ask 'who,' 'what,' 'where,' or 'why' questions, driven by curiosity and an expanding understanding of language.

title: Says first name, when asked
description: Child can tell you their first name when someone asks them.
sourceQuote: By 3 years, most children can say their first name when asked, showing self-awareness and the ability to share personal information.

title: Draws a circle when you show how
description: Child can copy a circle after watching you draw one, showing visual-motor integration.
sourceQuote: By 3 years, most children draw a circle when you show them how, demonstrating visual-motor skills and the ability to imitate.

title: Avoids touching hot objects when warned
description: Child understands and heeds warnings about danger, showing developing reasoning and self-control.
sourceQuote: By 3 years, most children avoid touching hot objects like a stove when you warn them, showing they understand danger and can exercise self-control.

title: Strings items together, like large beads or macaroni
description: Child has the fine motor skills and patience to thread objects onto a string.
sourceQuote: By 3 years, most children can string items together, like large beads or macaroni, showing fine motor precision and patience.

title: Puts on some clothes by themselves
description: Child can pull on pants, put arms through sleeves, or put on shoes (though not necessarily on the right feet).
sourceQuote: By 3 years, most children put on some clothes by themselves, like pulling up pants or slipping on a jacket, building independence.

title: Uses a fork
description: Child can spear food with a fork and bring it to their mouth fairly neatly.
sourceQuote: By 3 years, most children use a fork to eat, spearing food and bringing it to their mouth with good control.
